title: Indian Creek
field_incident_description: The Indian Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
field_incident_overview: The Indian Creek Fire started August 5, 2025, on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation. It was burning in grass, brush, Juniper and Ponderosa Pine in steep and rugged terrain that was challenging for firefighters to access.

title: White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER
field_incident_overview:
The White Sage Fire was started by lightning on July 9, 2025, near the community of White Sage approximately 15 miles southeast of Fredonia, Arizona, on the Bureau of Land Management’s Arizona Strip District. The wind-driven fire quickly grew onto the North Kaibab Ranger District despite the efforts of wildland firefighters who were able to respond a short time after the fire was first detected.

Driven by hot, dry, windy weather, the fire quickly grew and crossed onto the North Kaibab Ranger District by July 10. Command of the fire transferred command to the Color Country Team 2 Incident Management Team July 10 and was transferred on July 13 to Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 6. 

A Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team was ordered to assess the effects of the White Sage Fire to critical Forest Service values within the fire perimeter. The Team, led by BAER Team Leader Paul Brown, began assessing the Fire on August 1 and completed their findings and recommendations briefing to the Forest leadership on August 11.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Mountain Fire
field_incident_description: The Mountain incident is located near the area of the Mammoth fire which burned in July.  U.S. Forest Service-Modoc National Forest  Fire resources, including engines, crews, and fire suppression aircraft, are responding to a new fire incident visible from HWY 139 near Casuse Mountain with more resources on order. The Mountain Fire is approximately 250 acres burning in grass and brush with a moderate rate of spread.
field_incident_overview:
🔥8/12 Mountain Fire update 3:30 PM  🔥

The Mountain Fire is currently 30% contained at 980 acres, with no significant growth reported. The aerial support during this incident has been crucial, aiding in the fire line construction for the firefighters working on the ground. 

Today, crews are continuing mop-up operations, focusing on full suppression and containment of the fire. 

**Fire Weather:** Isolated critical conditions are expected today and Wednesday due to gusty winds and low relative humidity (RH). Dry conditions are expected to persist throughout the week, with temperatures gradually returning to near seasonal norms. A dry front is predicted to move through the region today and continue into Wednesday, which may bring increased wind speeds. These winds, coupled with low daytime RH, could create isolated areas of critical fire weather conditions. 

The public is urged to stay clear of areas where firefighters are actively working and to help prevent new fires from starting.

title: Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rock Fire was established as an incident at 12:37 a.m. on August 13, 2025. It was one of several lightning-caused fires that started between the evening of August 12 and the early morning hours of August 13 across the Boise and Payette National Forests. Located approximately 1.5 miles south of Tamarack Resort, some of the smaller fires in the area were extinguished, while others merged into what is now the Rock Fire.

The fire is burning in rugged, mountainous terrain, with steep slopes on the northwest and southeast flanks. The subalpine fir understory holds a heavy load of dead and downed fuels, contributing to challenging fire behavior and intensity.

title: King Fire
field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: A brush fire was reported at 1:00 am in the morning east of interstate 5 and north of Smokey Bear Rd. In the early hours of the fire, firefighters experienced dangerous rates of spread and the fire quickly grew to over 100 acres. The fire has continued to burn south towards Vista Del Lago. Two unoccupied RV's were destroyed at the Pyramid Lake RV park early on in the incident. The fire has attempted to cross Interstate 5 three times.

 

CURRENT CONDITION: The King fire is 100% contained. All road closures have been lifted.

title: Horn Fire
field_incident_description:
The Horn fire is located on private property and DNRC-managed land between Cliff Lake and Highway 87 in Madison County, near the Montana-Idaho border. Fuels in the area are primarily grass and brushy fuels.

Horn Creek Road, Cliff Lake Road, and Wade Lake Road are open as of 8/18. Wade Lake and Cliff Lake are also open to the public.
field_incident_overview:
The Horn Fire was reported around 2:30 pm on Wednesday, August 13th. The cause of fire was lightning. 

As of Monday 8/25, the Horn Fire is 2,800 acres and 100% contained. Crews should be finishing rehab today and then demobilizing. 

Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when recreating to avoid causing additional fires. Secure chains when towing and check MTFireInfo.org for fire restrictions. Beaverhead and Madison County are in Stage 1 restrictions, meaning campfires are not allowed unless in a developed campground with an established ring. Always fully extinguish your campfire until it is cold to the touch.

title: Elkhorn Fire - Idaho
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The Elkhorn Fire started on July 29th around 5 pm and was lightning caused. The fire is burning approximately 33 miles northwest of Stanley and is burning on a cliff face adjacent to the Middle Fork of the Salmon River and approximately seven river miles from Boundary Boat Launch.

Firefighters are using a confine (confine involves restricting the fire to a predetermined area, often using natural barriers or fuel breaks) and a point protection strategy (a wildfire response strategy which protects specific assets or highly valued resources from the wildfire without directly halting the continued spread of the wildfire). 

Fire managers are using infrared flights supplemented with reconnaissance flights as appropriate. This strategy limits exposure to firefighters and maximizes firefighting resources for other wildfires that may be discovered.

title: Washington Fire
field_incident_overview:
This page is covering the Washington Fire and the nearby Sheep Spring Fire.

The lightning caused Washington Fire was discovered on Wednesday, August 13, 2025. Firefighters are working to fully suppress the fire, with the top priority being the safety of both the public and firefighters.

On Friday, August 15, 2025 at 0600, the management of the Washington Fire transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1, led by Incident Commander, Carl Schwope. 

On August 19, 2025 the team assisted with the response to a new lightning caused fire on the Tonto. That became the Sheep Spring FIre and was transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1 on August 20, 2025.

Both fires were transitioned to local Type 3 teams on August 23 at 0600. 

Sheep Spring Fire transitioned back to the local unit (Type 5) and was placed in monitor and patrol status as of August 25 at 4 p.m.

To sign up for evacuation notices in Gila County, visit: https://gilacountyaz.genasys.com/portal/en

To sign up for evacuation notices in Coconino County, visit: https://www.coconino.az.gov/2612/Emergency-Notification-System

title: Bivens Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Bivens Creek fire was reported on August 13, 2025, around 6:16. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning just to the southwest of Ramshorn Mountain. The fire area consists of thick subalpine fir timber, with a large "snag" or hazard tree component and a high concentration of dead and downed fuels. The cause of the fire was from a thunderstorm. 

On August 30, 2025, at 6 PM, Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8 took over command of the Fire from Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 6.

September 8, 2025, at 7AM, a NWCIMT8 transferred command to a local Type 3 Incident Command Team.

Information about Air Quality can be found on the Fire and Smoke Map located on the AirNow website.  

Madison County Sherriff has issued a warning of evacuation residences in Wisconsin Creek, Noble Creek and Indian Creek. 

A National Forest System Area Closure is in effect for the Bivens and Cloudrest Fires.  The purpose of this Order is for public health and safety due to the Cloudrest and Bivens Fires. As depicted on Attachment A, the area closed by this Order is as follows: Sections 15-36 (T3S R4W), Sections 15-22 and 28-33 (T3S R3W), Sections 1-4, 9-15, 22-27 and 34-36 (T4S R4W), Sections 1-36 (T4S R3W),and  Sections 1-12 (T5S R3W).

There is a Temporary Flight Restriction in place over the fire area. The TFR is in place to provide a safe environment for firefighting aircraft operations. The TFR extends for seven nautical miles from the surface of the ground up to and including 15,000 feet. 

Using drones and flying private aircraft in the fire area can halt air operations and suppression efforts, jeopardizing the safety of all firefighting resources.

title: Red Canyon Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 will transfer command to the local unit at 6 pm on 08/27/2025. A Type 4 organization will assume command of the fire.  This will be the final update for the Red Canyon Fire unless fire conditions change.

Any future inquiries for the Red Canyon Fire, please contact: 

BLM, Worland Field Office 

307-347-5100

The lightning caused Red Canyon fire was reported on Wednesday, August 14th east of Thermopolis, WY in Hot Springs County.  The fire is burning on a combination of BLM, state, and private lands.  Extreme weather conditions in light dry fuels heightened fire activity and the Red Canyon Fire grew to over 100,000 acres in 4 days.    

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 assumed command of the fire on Monday August 18th with full-suppression efforts and public and firefighter safety the highest priorities. 

Containment continued to increase thanks to the hard work of firefighters.  Crews continue to patrol the perimeter of the fire and the majority of suppression repair efforts have been completed. 

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 would like to sincerely thank our partners, cooperators, and residents for welcoming the team and supporting suppression efforts. Together, we accomplished the mission while maintaining both public and firefighter safety.

title: Windy Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
INCIDENT SUMMARY

This fire is jointly managed under a full suppression strategy between the Bureau of Land Management, the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC) and Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 1. Northern Rockies CIMT1, led by Incident Commander Brent Olson, assumed command of the Windy Rock Fire at 7 am on September 7.

Lightning ignited the Windy Rock Fire at approximately 1700 on August 14, 2025, in the Hoodoo Mountain Wilderness Study Area, north of Gold Creek and Phosphate in Powel County, Montana. The fire was first reported at 100 acres, but grew quickly in steep, heavily timbered terrain with significant dead and down trees.

EVACUATION ORDER

The emergency evacuation order for the residents in the OS Properties / GMPOA Reforestation area - South of Helmville has been downgraded to an evacuation warning. 

This warning affects residents in the area East of Cottonwood Creek, Dry Cottonwood Creek and Kelley Creek.

For more evacuation information, follow the Powell County Sheriff’s Office Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/powellcountysheriff.

title: Dragon Bravo Fire - DOI Burned Area Emergency Response - BAER
field_incident_overview:
On August 21, a Department of the Interior Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team arrived at the Dragon Bravo Fire to identify potential risks to human life and safety, as well and critical natural and cultural resources in Grand Canyon National Park and on BLM-Arizona Strip District lands.

The BAER program is designed to address emergency stabilization issues related to wildland fire and prescribes emergency treatments to minimize threats to life and property resulting from the effects of fire. The program also addresses fire-damaged lands that are unlikely to recover naturally and to repair or replace minor facilities damaged by fire that are not critical to life and safety. This may include restoring native plant communities, treating noxious weed infestations, stabilizing trails, and replacing interpretive signs that were impacted by the fire.  

Team members are from the Bureau of Land Management, US Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, National Park Service, and US Forest Service. The BAER team will produce a BAER Plan specific to the Dragon Bravo Fire which will identify measures to reduce hazards and reduce further resource damage.

For more information on fire suppression efforts on the Dragon Bravo Fire, please visit the Dragon Bravo Fire Inciweb page.
field_title_and_unit: AZGCP Dragon Bravo Fire DOI Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Sleeper Ranch Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Sleeper Ranch fire experienced extreme fire behavior and rapid growth during the Initial Attack. Aircraft continue to work the fire today as additional ground resources work their way to the fire.  

A Type 3 Incident Management Team has been ordered and is enroute.

title: Mire
field_incident_overview: The Mire Fire is located on the Lochsa-Powell Ranger District of the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests in northern Idaho approximately 25 miles west of Powell Idaho. The fire is burning in steep rugged terrain in proximity to old fire scars with many standing dead hazard trees. Fire activity varies daily from smoldering and creeping to isolated group torching and short runs when the daily inversion lifts and winds increase.

title: McAllister Fire
field_incident_description:
The McAllister Fire is located on private, state, and BLM land 3 miles south or Norris, and 3 miles north of Ennis Lake, on either side of HWY 287. The fire is burning mainly grass and scattered patches of trees.
There is an evacuation warning for residents in the area between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West, and US Highway 287.
field_incident_overview:
The McAllister Fire was reported around 5:15pm, Saturday August 16th. The cause of the fire was lightning. 

As of Wednesday, 8/27, the fire is estimated at 3,560 acres with 95% containment. 

Crews are working around the perimeter patrolling the line. 

Resources will continue operations with the objective to creating a cold, secure buffer around the entire perimeter working for about the next week.

The evacuation warning has been lifted as of 8/20/25 for the areas between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West and US Highway 287 (between mile markers 61 and 64). There are no current road closures in place.

With moisture coming the next few days, crews will be patrolling and doing suppression repair.

title: Knowles Fire
field_incident_description: Incident is located 6 miles east of Paradise
field_incident_overview: The Knowles Fire was reported on August 17, 2025. It is located along the Flathead River near the Full Curl Wildlife Management Area. The fire is being jointly managed under a full suppression strategy by the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC) and the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes (CSKT).

title: Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS
field_incident_description: US Forest Service Burned Area Emergency response on the 77,648 acres of Kaibab National Forest portion of the 144,504 acre Dragon Bravo Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dragon Bravo Fire started early in the afternoon on Friday July 4th, 2025, by lightning on the North Rim of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park. Suppression resources responded immediately. Firefighters constructed containment lines taking advantage of favorable terrain where possible to stop the fire spread.

On Friday July 11th, 2025, the Dragon Bravo Fire was affected by strong and unfavorable northwest winds associated with a passing weather front. Consequently, the Dragon Bravo Fire exhibited extreme fire behavior and jumped multiple containment features. In the following days fire behavior continued to be very active, driven by hot temperatures, low relative humidities, and continued strong winds. Facilities in the North Rim developed area were impacted during this time and damage assessments are ongoing. The fire moved onto the North Kaibab Ranger District of the Kaibab National Forest on July 23.

On Monday July 14th, 2025, at 6:00 am Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 4 took command of the Dragon Bravo Fire. They managed the fire until 6:00 am on Monday July 28th, 2025, when Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 2 took command of the fire.

On Sunday August 10th, 2025, Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command of the Dragon Bravo Fire and will continue to manage the fire under a full suppression strategy while also ensuring firefighter/first responder and public safety.

In the last few days, suppression resources have made significant progress constructing and reinforcing containment lines. More favorable weather conditions have resulted in lower fire intensity in many areas. Suppression repair in select areas of the fire is in progress and will increase in the coming days. 

On Monday August 18, The Forest Service Burned Area Emergency (BAER) Team arrived to identify and manage potential risks to resources on National Forest System lands and reduce these threats through appropriate emergency measures to protect human life and safety, property, and critical natural or cultural resources on the Kaibab National Forest portion of the Dragon Bravo Fire.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS

title: La Plata
field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Firefighters will continue to utilize both direct and indirect tactics to guide fire behavior toward natural barriers such as treeline scree fields and minimize threats to private property, communities, infrastructure, watersheds, and other critical assets. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.

title: Derby Fire
field_incident_overview:
As of Saturday, September 6th at 6:00a.m., a Type 3 incident management organization has taken command of the Derby fire, with Patrick Kieran as Incident Commander. 

The Derby Fire was ignited by lightning on an extremely steep cliff face in a remote area near the Flat Tops Wilderness on Saturday evening, August 16, 2025. Initial attack efforts by smokejumpers on Sunday were hindered by rollout of burning material, repeatedly igniting the slope below the main fire. 

Protection of life and property are key objectives for managing this fire.

title: Sandbar 2 Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning/Natural
field_incident_overview: In the early afternoon on August 19, fire personnel responded to a smoke report just north of Flesher Pass. Fire personnel responded immediately utilizing both helicopters and airtankers to assist hand crews putting in direct line. Dry fuels, low humidity, and warm weather led to rapid fire growth on the Sandbar 2 fire. Please be mindful of increased fire personnel on Flesher Pass Road #279 and slow down to protect our firefighters’ safety. Please avoid stopping on the road or pullouts as this affects firefighter safety and operations. On Friday August 22, at 0700 hrs., command of the fire was transferred to Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8, with Ed Hyatt serving as Incident Commander. On August 28, 2025, at 0700, a local Type 4 incident management organization will have taken command of the fire.

title: West Fork Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The West Fork Fire Started on 8/19/2025, located 23 miles northwest of West Yellowstone, Montana, in the South Madison's just North of the Beaver Creek FS cabin, Hebgen Ranger District, Custer Gallatin National Forest.

The fire does not currently pose a threat to Big Sky. Please stay away from aviation working at Hebgen Lake. Aviation aircraft may be dipping out of Hebgen Lake. DO NOT operate drones in the fire area or the Hebgen Lake area, this will cause all firefighting aircraft to be grounded immediately. There is a temporary Flight Restriction in place in the fire area.

No evacuations ordered at this point in time.

title: Twin
field_incident_overview: The Twin Fire is a lightning caused fire burning in the remote backcountry of the North Fork Ranger District on the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests. Public and firefighter safety continues to be our highest priority. Please be mindful of closures and use caution when recreating in the area near the fire.

title: Dollar Lake Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dollar Lake Fire is burning in the Green River Lakes area of the Bridger-Teton National Forest's Pinedale Ranger District. The fire was reported at 2:16 p.m. on Thursday, August 21.

Dollar Lake is located along a 25-mile dirt and gravel road that follows the Green River through the national forest. The road is a popular camping and recreation site. In a matter of hours on Aug. 21, the wind-driven fire grew from 20 acres to 600 acres in size. The fast-moving fire prompted the Sublette County Sheriff's office to immediately issue a road closure and evacuation of the area.

The cause of the fire has not been determined.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304).

title: Willow Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Willow Creek Fire was reported on Friday, August 22 on the Greys River District of the Bridger-Teton National Forest, burning in timber southwest of the town of Smoot. Initial resources included an engine and helitack working to suppress the fire, with air attack quickly on scene utilizing three helicopters and two air tankers. This is a full suppression fire.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304)

A Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect for the Willow Creek Fire response area. Click here to read more about the TFR and the important life and safety restrictions on drone use.

field_incident_overview:

Multiple agencies responded including U.S. Forest Service, Kern County Fire Department, Bureau of Land Management, Kern County Sheriff's Office, California Highway Patrol, and Caltrans. The terrain is steep and rocky, with extremely dry vegetation. The cause of this fire is under investigation.

title: East
field_incident_overview: The East Fire is located on the Lochsa-Powell Ranger District of the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests in northern Idaho approximately 18 miles southwest of Lolo Pass. The fire is burning in steep rugged terrain in proximity to old fire scars with many standing dead hazard trees. Fire activity varies daily from smoldering and creeping to isolated group torching and short runs when the daily inversion lifts and winds increase. Aviation resources are being utilized as weather conditions allow to reduce fire activity.

title: Flat Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The Flat Fire began on the afternoon of August 21st approximately seven miles southwest of Culver, Oregon. Local fire departments, the Lower Bridge Rangeland Fire Protection Association, and the Central Oregon Fire Management Services Type 3 team responded and provided initial attack. Warm and windy conditions, along with low fuel moistures, led to rapid fire spread. 

Oregon Governor Tina Kotek invoked the Conflagration Act on the morning of August 22nd due to threats to life and property. The Oregon Department of Forestry Complex Incident Management Team 3 and Oregon State Fire Marshal Red Team assumed unified command of the incident at 1800 on August 23rd. 

Following several days of active fire behavior and point protection around homes, crews worked overnight on August 24th to fully line spot fires and slop over, and to increase hand and dozer line. 67% containment was reported on September 2nd. As of August 27th, the Deschutes County Sheriff's Office has reported that five primary residences and 11 other structures were destroyed, and two residences and two structures were damaged. 

A community meeting was held at the Sisters High School at 6 pm on August 25th and the recording can be viewed on YouTube at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I55pOT1H4Nw

title: Garnet Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning fire
field_incident_overview:
UPDATES: Morning Update |  Actualización Diaria de Incendio | Morning Ops Briefing

MAPS: Public Information Map | Progression Map

AIR QUALITY: AirNow.gov

 

Special Announcement:

Garnet Fire oﬀicials will host an in-person community meeting to provide the current fire situation and address questions. The meeting will take place on Thursday, September 11, at 6:00 PM at the Shaver Lake Community Center, 41344 Tollhouse Road, Shaver Lake, CA. 

 

Current Situation: 

Favorable weather continued through the night with cooler temperatures and increased humidity, with no movement of the fire outside its current footprint. Crews worked to improve containment lines, mopping up 100’ inside the line by extinguishing burning stumps, hotspots, ashpits, and mitigating hazard trees. Crews were also able to make progress extinguishing spot fires from the previous day on the northwest side near Bear Meadow. 

Weather: 

An inversion layer is expected to remain over the fire area until midday. Partly to mostly cloudy and smoky conditions are forecast for today, with a 10% chance of showers and thunderstorms.

Air Quality:

The fire is expected to produce low to moderate amounts of smoke today. Changes in wind direction are likely to reduce smoke impacts across the region; however, some areas may still experience air quality levels ranging from moderate to unhealthy. You can check your local air quality at: airnow.gov/. 

Evacuations and Road Closures – No significant changes 

The Fresno County Sheriff's Office has issued evacuation orders and warnings and road closures for areas affected by the Garnet Fire in the Sierra National Forest. Full updates on the fire and evacuation maps are available from the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office. The evacuation map is an interactive tool that allows residents to search by their physical address, general location, or evacuation zone to determine the latest impact of the fire to residents. 

Forest Closure – No significant changes

The Sierra National Forest implemented a partial closure on August 28, 2025, in response to the full suppression effort on the Garnet Fire. The partial closure order was coordinated with the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office, along with multiple local, state and federal agency cooperators, to identify the minimum area necessary for the safety of firefighting resources and forest visitors.  For a copy of the closure and map please visit the Sierra National Forest website at: Sierra National Forest | Garnet Fire Closure Order | Forest Service

title: Emigrant Fire
field_incident_overview:
QUICK LINKS

Daily Update (PDF)

Daily Map (PDF) 

Daily Operations Update (Video)

Daily Weather Update (Video)

Facebook:  Emigrant Fire    

Smoke: https://www.airnow.gov

Public information: https://linktr.ee/2025.emigrantfire 

 

CURRENT STATUS: Firefighters are using ridges, roads, and rivers as holding lines. Roads and ridges provide more effective and safer access for containment work on the fire line, while rivers act as natural breaks in fuels. Crews continue to snag, chip, and reinforce these lines. 

The fire is currently being sustained by heavy fuels, including dead and downed trees, which are slower to absorb moisture and retain heat for extended periods. The recent rainfall has had a notable dampening effect on lighter, fine fuels such as grasses, small twigs, and leaf litter, which are more reactive to moisture. By saturating these materials, the rain has significantly reduced surface fire behavior, slowed the fire's forward progression, and minimized visible smoke across the affected area. While overall fire activity has decreased due to the wet conditions, areas with heavy fuel loading remain a concern. These fuels can continue to smolder deep within the fire perimeter and may reignite surface fuels once conditions dry out. 

Today, we pause to honor the sacrifice so many showed on 9-11-2001. We would like to take a moment to recognize the remarkable altruism, concern for the well-being of others, independent of personal benefit or reciprocity, displayed by crews. Whether responding to urgent needs, offering support in moments of crisis, or simply showing up with unwavering dedication, these acts of solidarity are deeply appreciated—and never forgotten by the fire community. 

WEATHER:  Operations are being monitored for safety.

Ever wonder how or why a fire is named?  Here's a little info and policy.  Read more.  

WEATHER & FIRE BEHAVIOR: Temperatures are expected to be in the high 60s to 70s with chances of rain and thunderstorms. More rain is possible on Saturday or Sunday.  Relative humidity will be lower this afternoon. Detailed forecast available at https://forecast.weather.gov/  Fire behavior will remain subdued as cooler temperatures, rain, and high humidity prevent rapid fire growth, however heavy fuels will remain smoldering especially in closed canopy timber.

RESTRICTIONS & CLOSURES:  

Willamette National Forest closure order for the fire can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/willamette/alerts/emigrant-fire-closure-order. Willamette National Forest fire restrictions can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/willamette/alerts/temporary-fire-public-use-restrictions-are-effect

Umpqua National Forest closure can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/umpqua/alerts/emigrant-fire-closure-order-no-06-15-03-25-02. Umpqua National Forest fire restrictions can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/umpqua/alerts/public-use-restrictions-level-2.

SMOKE: Air quality is expected to gradually improve over the next few days as emissions from the Emigrant Fire decrease. In low lying areas, fog may mix with smoke and reduce visibility. Smoke and air quality information is available at https://www.oregonsmoke.org/ and https://www.airnow.gov.

DRONES AND AVIATION SAFETY:  The Federal Aviation Administration in conjunction with Fire Management has issued a Notice to Airman (NOTAM) for all aircraft below 11,500’ MSL.  For details, please visit: https://tfr.faa.gov/tfr3/?page=detail_5_7025  Wildfires are a no-fly zone for unauthorized aircraft, including drones. If you fly, we can’t.  For more information, visit http://knowbeforeyoufly.org.

BACKGROUND: The lightning-caused Emigrant Fire was reported on Aug. 24, 2025. The fire ignited in a remote area 3 miles southwest of Indigo Springs Campground. The fire spread rapidly through the 2009 Tumblebug Fire burn scar, which has many standing and fallen dead trees plus dense brush, and few opportunities for direct control of the fire.  Indirect control lines were established around the fire, many along roads or in locations previously used by the Tumblebug Fire. As of early September, the Emigrant Fire has reached some of these control lines, mainly on the northern part of the fire. 

The Emigrant Fire is now spreading in areas that were not recently burned. Fire growth has been slower due to greener fuels, but is still active, depending upon the weather. 

ABOUT THE FOREST:  The Willamette National Forest covers an impressive swath of the Cascade Mountains in Oregon, where volcanic peaks tower above iconic Douglas firs, and crystal-clear waters crash over immense waterfalls. This forest encompasses 1,675,407 acres, and within that landscape, you will find diverse habitats, numerous recreation opportunities, and fascinating history.

At 10,495 feet above sea level, Mt. Jefferson is Oregon’s second-highest peak and the tallest point within the Forest. Six other major Cascade peaks can also be found here, including Three Fingered Jack, Mt. Washington, the Three Sisters, and Diamond Peak.

title: Ransome Fire
field_incident_overview: The Ransome Fire was detected on August 21, 2025 and from a previous lightning storm. It is burning in the Quartz Creek drainage 11 miles northwest of Libby, MT in the 2017 West Fork Fire scar.

title: Dillon Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dillon Fire was detected August 25, 2025 in the area of Dillon Creek just west of the Klamath River about 16 miles north of Orleans, California. The fire quickly grew to more than 300 acres by evening with extreme fire behavior and long-range spotting. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on August 29. California Complex Incident Management Team 6 (CA-CIMT 6) will assume command of the Dillon Fire on Thursday, September 11. The incident command post is in Happy Camp, CA.  

Evacuation Orders and Warnings are in effect. For current information on evacuations visit https://protect.genasys.com.

title: Swift Complex
field_incident_description: The fires, which started on the afternoon of Aug 25, 2025, are burning in steep, rugged, and remote terrain and is moving north toward Granite Peak. Most of the fire footprint is currently within the Trinity Alps Wilderness.
field_incident_overview: The command of Swift Complex is being transferred to Shasta-Trinity National Forest on September 10, 2025. The command of the Lick Fire was transferred to the Forest Service on September 7, 2025, at 7 AM. The Peak Fire is west of Lake Trinity and east of Mule Creek, while the Lick Fire is in Poison Canyon, southeast of the Carrville community.

title: Martin
field_incident_overview:
The Martin Fire was sparked from one of more than 320 strikes from a dry lightning storm that passed over the area on the evening of August 26, 2025. It is burning at high elevation in forests that have dried out all summer with excessive heat and drought conditions. 

Closures: Trail, road, and area closures are in place to provide for public and firefighter safety in the vicinity of the Martin Fire, northwest of Holden, WA. https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/okanogan-wenatchee/alerts/martin-fire-closure-chelan-ranger-district

Evacuations: Holden Village and Rio Tinto Mine facilities are at a level two “get set”. Please visit Chelan County Emergency Management’s website at https://www.co.chelan.wa.us/emergency-management/pages/active-emergencies for official evacuation information.

Fire Information: Updates will occur when there is significant new information.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/OkaWenNF/

title: Blue Fire - Klamath National Forest
field_incident_overview:
California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) will assume command of the Dillon Fire on Sunday, August 31. Incident Command Post (ICP) will be established at 7:00 a.m. in Happy Camp, CA.  

On the evening of August 26, 2025 the Blue Fire ignited in the area of Blue Creek on the south side of the Klamath National Forest, just west of the Klamath River, 4 miles south of Seiad, California. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 1(CIMT 1) assumed command of the Blue Fire on August 29.  California Incident Management Team 6 (CA-IMT 6) will assume command of the Blue Fire on Thursday, September 11.  The incident Command post is in Happy Camp, CA. 

CLOSURES: For official map and official Forest closure information around the Blue Fire, please visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/klamath/alerts/blue-fire-closure-order.
field_title_and_unit: CAKNF Blue Fire Klamath National Forest

title: Crown Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Crown Creek fire began early in the evening of August 29, 2025, approximately one mile southeast of Marble, Washington. Around the same time, the Blackhawk Mountain fire began nearby, approximately seven miles south of Northport, Washington. Both were caused by the same lightning storm.

Multiple engines, crews and aircraft from local fire departments and WA Department of Natural Resources responded as initial attack. Shortly after, Northeast Washington Interagency Incident Management Team 1 (Type 3 team) took command of both incidents. Firefighters were challenged with a Red Flag warning and heat advisory conditions, which fueled the fire growth. Complex Incident Management NW Team 12 assumed command of both fires on Sept. 2, due to the fire exceeding the Type 3 team’s capacity.

title: Wildcat Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Wildcat Fire was started by lightning in the William O. Douglas Wilderness and was first reported on Monday, August 25, 2025. It grew slowly until Saturday, August 30, when winds caused increased fire activity, with the fire spotting and flanking. Two helicopters and 4 scooper airtanker aircraft dropped water on the fire. Scoopers dipped water out of Bumping Lake. Fire crews scouted for opportunities to go direct on the 28th and 29th. Increased fire activity on Saturday did not allow this effort to continue. 

Firefighters were challenged with hot and dry conditions, which fueled fire growth. Complex Incident Management NW Team 10 assumed command of the fire on September 3, 2025, due to the fire exceeding the Type 3 team's capacity.

Due to extreme fire activity and spread, the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest updated its road, trail and area closure (9/2/25). See the complete order and a map under the "Closures" tab on this site.

Yakima County increased the evacuation level for Goose Prairie and Bumping River Road residents to a LEVEL 2 GET SET.

title: Katy Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Katy Creek fire began the afternoon of August 30, 2025, approximately six miles northwest of Kettle Falls, Washington. This is a lightning-caused incident.

Multiple engines, crews and aircraft from the US Forest Service and the nearby Crown Creek/Blackhawk Mountain fire management team responded as initial attack. Shortly after, Complex Incident Management NW Team 12 assumed command of this fire on Sept. 2, due to the fire exceeding the Forest’s firefighting capacity.

Firefighters have been challenged with a Red Flag warning and heat advisory conditions which fueled the fire growth.

title: White Pine
field_incident_overview:
Public and firefighter safety remain the top priority. Please respect area closures and exercise caution when recreating near the fire. Expect heavier road traffic along ID Hwy 6, FS-768, and FS-1423 as crews move to and from the incident. 

NOTE: Giant White Pine Campground and Laird Park Campground are both currently closed to the public due to the close proximity to this fire and the evolving need to accommodate incoming firefighting personnel.

title: Root Fire
field_incident_overview: The Root Fire was discovered September 1, 2025 north of Castle Creek and west of Castella.  Law enforcement officers from the Forest Service have determined that the Root Fire was caused by an escaped campfire. The fire is burning in Timber understory and grass in steep terrain. Firefighters are working to keep the fire north of Forest Road 39N25; South of the Castle Crags Wilderness; East of Whalen Summit and West of the North Fork of Castle Creek. The fire is burning in steep, rugged terrain with seasonally dry and receptive fuel.

title: Rattlesnake
field_incident_overview:
On September 1, 2025, the Rattlesnake Fire was reported on the Colville Reservation near Inchelium, WA. The fire - named Rattlesnake Fire- is burning in steep thick timber ground and grass sage steep within the old fire scar of the 2003 Rattlesnake Fire. 

Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command at 0600 on September 5th, 2025.

Evacuations orders: There are evacuations in place for both fires, including Level 3 “GO NOW”. View and download the two maps on Inciweb: https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-maps-gallery/wacoa-rattlesnake 

For updates regarding the Rattlesnake Fire, you can follow https://www.facebook.com/CCTBroadcasts on social media. Videos are available to those without Facebook accounts using that link.

Smoke Outlook: Air quality can change quickly. Know your risk to wildfire smoke and plan to reduce exposure. For current smoke reports visit https://fire.airnow.gov 

Air Space Restrictions: A Temporary Flight Restriction is in place over the Rattlesnake and Lynx Mountain Fires- including some areas on the east and south side of the Columbia River. If you fly, we can’t. Every time a drone is spotted near the fire all aircraft are grounded until we can be sure the drone is clear of this area. http://knowbeforeyoufly.org

title: Ulm Creek Fire
field_incident_overview: The Ulm Creek Fire, located approximately 6 miles north of Little Guard Peak and approximately 5 miles east of Spion Kop on the ID/MT border. The fire is visible from Heron, Montana. It started on 8/30/2025 from abundant lightning that came through the region. It is burning in the Ulm Peak Fire scar from 2006. Initial attack efforts included district firefighters and engines, a Hotshot crew, and aviation support. Due to unseasonably warm and dry weather, the fire has exceeded initial attack efforts with the largest growth to date occurring overnight on 9/1/2025.

title: Tacoma Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Tacoma Creek fire is burning 15 miles northwest of Cusick, WA. The lightning-caused fire started on September 1, 2025, on private land. The fire soon reached U.S. Forest Service lands on the Colville National Forest and land administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the Little Pend Orielle National Wildlife Refuge. A checkerboard of private and federal government lands creates complexity. Firefighters are using a variety of tactics to suppress the fire and protect values identified from all impacted agencies and landowners.

The Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 7 took command of the fire on September 7, 2025.

title: Green Mtn Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho and three miles east of Kilroy Bay. The fire was discovered 8/29/2025 at 6:27pm. The fire is located just below Green Monarch Mountain on the upper 1/3 of the slope in difficult terrain overlooking Lake Pend Oreille. Aviation resources were assigned to the fire beginning on 8/30/2025.

Northern Rockies Team 9, a Type 3 Incident Management Team, assumed command of the Green Rattle Complex on September 5, 2025, at 0600 hours. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).  

Dense, drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest, northern Rocky Mountains, and Canada has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.

Several road and trail closures are in effect, and additional road closures are pending.  See full closure order descriptions on the Inciweb closures tab or the forest's websites Idaho Panhandle National Forests. A portion of Forest Service Road (FSR) 278 is closed between Johnson Saddle and the FSR2706 intersection, including all roads and trails initiating from or bisecting that area (FSR1068, as well as Trails 68, 69, and 105). As long as fire behavior and activity allow, the Forest will keep FSR2706 open as an alternate route for FSR278. However, forest users are advised that FSR2706 is generally narrower, and high-clearance vehicles are recommended. 

There is a Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) in place over the fire area to ensure a safe environment for firefighting aircraft operations. The use of drones or private aircraft in the fire area can halt air operations and suppression efforts, jeopardizing the safety of all firefighting personnel. Aircraft are supporting fire suppression operations as needed, so please avoid boating or recreating in areas where aircraft are accessing Lake Pend Oreille. Do not fly unmanned aircraft (drones) near the fire areas, as this poses a hazard to pilots and ground crews who rely on aerial support. Remember: If you fly, we can’t!

title: Log Fire - Klamath National Forest
field_incident_overview:
The Log Fire started in the end of August after several days of thunderstorms passed over the Klamath National Forest. It is burning in a steep and remote area of the Marble Wilderness, about two miles northwest of English Peak. The difficult terrain and competition with other incidents for resources have hampered suppression efforts.

California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) assumed command of the Log Fire on Sunday, August 31. California Incident Management Team 6 (CA-CIMT6) will assume command at 7:00am, September 11. Incident Command Post (ICP) was established at 7:00am in Happy Camp, CA.

An emergency area closure is in place for the Log Fire, available here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/klamath/alerts/log-fire-closure-order
field_title_and_unit: CAKNF Log Fire Klamath National Forest

title: Rattle Mountain Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rattle Mountain Fire was first detected on Tuesday, September 2, 2025, burning adjacent to Rattle Mountain, north of FSR473. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana. 

Northern Rockies Team 9, a Type 3 Incident Management Team, assumed command of the Green Rattle Complex on September 5, 2025, at 0600 hours. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).

title: Lower Sugarloaf Fire
field_incident_overview:
Lower Sugarloaf Fire is a lightning-caused fire located near Sugarloaf Lookout. The fire is burning partially in the footprint of the 1994 Tyee Fire and the 2018 Cougar Creek Fire, as well as thick timber and brush that has not seen fire within record.  

Smoke is very visible to the communities of Plain, Leavenworth, Wenatchee, and Entiat. 

Chelan County Sheriff’s Office has issued a Level 1 Evacuation Advisory (Stay Alert), Level 2 Evacuation Notice (Be Ready) and Level 3 Evacuation (Go!) for parts of the fire area, please visit https://www.co.chelan.wa.us/emer.../pages/active-emergencies for the latest evacuation information.

A Forest Service closure is also in effect around the fire area.  https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-publication/waowf-lower-sugarloaf-fire/lower-sugarloaf-fire-area-forest-closure09-07-2025

title: Labor Mountain Fire
field_incident_overview: The Labor Mountain Fire started on Monday, September 1st. It is burning between Standup and Stafford Creek drainages about 10 miles northeast of Cle Elum, WA. It is actively burning in very steep terrain in one of the drier areas on the Cle Elum Ranger District. The fire is burning in a popular recreation area, with many resources that are at risk, including 12 trailheads, recreation residences, Camp Wahoo and the Teanaway Community Forest and historic guard station. Public and fire fighter safety is the top priority.

title: Cedar Fire
field_incident_overview: The Cedar Fire is being managed by California Interagency Incident Management Team 2 until Tuesday, September 9 at 0700.

title: Snow Peak
field_incident_overview: On September 1, 2025, Snow Peak fire was reported in Ferry County, 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is located in a remote area approximately 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is burning in an inventoried roadless area with very difficult access by foot. Resources responding include crews, air attack, and helicopters. The Snow Peak cabin, a valuable recreation site in the alpine area NW of the fire, has been prepped with structure wrap and there have been past fuel treatments in the immediate vicinity of the cabin which significantly lowers the risk of impact.

title: Timber Butte
field_incident_overview:
The Timber Butte fire was reported on the afternoon of September 3rd at approximately 3:00 p.m. Burning in a remote area within the Hidden Pasture Creek Wilderness Area west of Dell, the fire was first reported as visible smoke near Little Water Canyon. Initial attack resources responded, and additional resources were ordered. The fire quickly grew, given the windy conditions associated with the passage of a dry cold front through the area. The fire was estimated at 1,062 acres by the evening hours and 2,245 acres by noon the next day. Given minimal fire behavior, the fire showed no measurable growth over subsequent days.

The fire is burning in steep, rocky terrain in a remote area; these conditions pose challenges to safe access, firefighting operations, and timely medical response if needed.

The fire is burning on lands managed by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. 

The cause of the fire is undetermined and is under investigation.

title: Green Rattle Complex
field_incident_overview:
Northern Rockies Team 9, a Type 3 Incident Management Team, assumed command of the Green Rattle Complex on September 5, 2025, at 0600 hours. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).  

All of the fires are lightning-caused fires which began as the result of storms between Friday, August 29 and Monday, September 2.

The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana.  The Spruce Fire is located approximately twelve miles southwest of Troy, Montana; and the Spruce Ridge Fire is located approximately thirteen miles southwest of Troy, Montana.  

Green Mtn. Fire:  35 acres; 0% containment

Rattle Mountain Fire:  115 acres; 0% containment

Spruce Fire:  228 acres; 0% containment

Spruce Ridge Fire: 80 acres; 0% containment

See the full road and trail closure descriptions on Inciweb, as well as the Idaho Panhandle National Forests and Kootenai National Forest websites: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/idahopanhandle/alerts, https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/kootenai/alerts. A portion of the Green Mtn. Fire area is closed between Johnson Saddle and the FSR2706 intersection, including all roads and trails initiating/bisecting that area (FSR1063, as well as trails 68, 69, and 105). As long as fire activity allows, the Forest will keep FSR2706 open as an alternate route for FSR278; however, forest users are advised that FSR2706 is generally a narrower route, and high-clearance vehicles are advised. There is a separate road closure at FSR332 (Bunco Road), FSR258, FSR534, and FSR911 for timber activities and is unrelated to fire operations. A road closure on a portion of the FSR473 and FSR603 is in place in vicinity of the Spruce, Spruce Ridge, and Rattle Mountain fires. Please avoid the general area to allow access for firefighters and equipment.

Dense, drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest and northern Rocky Mountains has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.

There is a Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) in place over the fire area to ensure a safe environment for firefighting aircraft operations. The use of drones or private aircraft in the fire area can halt air operations and suppression efforts, jeopardizing the safety of all firefighting personnel. Aircraft are supporting fire suppression operations as needed, so please avoid boating or recreating in areas where aircraft are accessing Lake Pend Oreille. Do not fly unmanned aircraft (drones) near the fire areas, as this poses a hazard to pilots and ground crews who rely on aerial support. Remember: If you fly, we can’t!

title: Lynx Mountain
field_incident_overview: The Lynx Mountain Fire is burning 7 miles northwest of Inchelium and northeast of Twin Lakes.  Discovered on Sept. 2, hot, dry days contributed to significant initial fire growth.

title: Perry Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning-caused wildfire north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex.
field_incident_overview:
On August 27, following storms across the area, a lightning-caused fire was reported north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex. 

Lake usage: Visitors recreating on Ross Lake should keep away from aerial resources, such as helicopters, utilizing the lake as a water source for firefighting suppression efforts. 

Smoke and air quality: Take precautions when recreating outdoors when heavy smoke is present. Individuals who are sensitive to poor air quality or those with respiratory problems may want to limit outdoor activities. Review smoke forecasts at https://fire.airnow.gov. 

Area, trail, and camp closures: Visitors should check the park Fire Closures page prior to a visit for up-to-date trail and camp closure information. Closures are in place to protect the public.

Fire restrictions: Fire restrictions remain in effect in all areas of the park complex. Campfires are banned in all portions of North Cascades National Park Service Complex – North Cascades National Park, Ross Lake National Recreation Area, and Lake Chelan National Recreation Area. This includes all National Park Service lands and campgrounds along State Route 20 as well as Hozomeen and the entire Stehekin Valley.

title: Marks Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Marks Creek Fire was reported just after noon on September 2nd, burning in timber and brush approximately 18 miles east of Prineville, Oregon on Ochoco National Forest lands. Aggressive initial attack included engines, dozers, single engine super scoopers, helicopters, large air tankers, and other air and ground resources.

The Central Oregon Fire Management Service (COFMS) Type 3 Incident Management Team, Incident Commander Fore, assumed command of the fire the morning of September 3rd.  Operations focused on establishing and strengthening control lines. 

COFMS Type 3 Team transitioned command of the Marks Creek Fire to Oregon Department of Forestry's Complex Incident Management Team 2, Incident Commander Matt Howard at 6:00 p.m. on September 4th. Crews continue to focus operations on reinforcing containment lines, patrolling the perimeter for spot fires and slop overs, and working to construct fireline to limit fire growth.  

Firefighting activity and smoke may impact travel on Hwy 26 in the fire area.

The cause of the fire is under investigation.

title: Bridge Fire - OR
field_incident_overview:
The Bridge Fire was reported on 9/3/2025 at 10:29 pm on the Malheur National Forest, within the Blue Mountain Ranger District. The fire is located approximately 9.9 miles northeast of Prairie City, near Dixie Lookout.

Fire crews are actively engaged in suppression efforts, with additional resources enroute to assist. The fire is burning in timber and brush within a steep, and roadless area. The cause of the fire is undetermined at this time. Due to the steep, rugged terrain in which the fire is located and the large amount of heavy, down and dead fuels present, the fire will remain on the landscape until a season ending event such as heavy rain or snow. Firefighters will work to limit the spread of the fire and protect values at risk while accounting for public and firefighter safety.

Motorists traveling along Highway 26 could see increased traffic and visible smoke, as firefighting operations continue.

For all evacuation information please go to:
Genasys Evacuation Map - https://protect.genasys.com/hazards/2001c3ee-af7d-4aa9-827a-232b150669fd?z=10.000105433629999&latlon=44.62346226723207%2C-118.62319026453702

For Closure information please go to:
Malheur National Forest | Bridge Fire Area Closure | Forest Service - https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/malheur/newsroom/releases/bridge-fire-area-closure-updated

title: Moon Complex
field_incident_description: Wildland Fire
field_incident_overview:
On September 3, a lightning event on the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest caused a number of fires in the vicinity of the Rogue River about 10 miles northeast of Agness, OR. Six of these made up the initial Moon Complex: the Backbone, Brushy, Pinnacle, Tate, Paradise, and Stair fires. As of September 8, the Paradise, Stair, and Brushy fires burned into the perimeters of other fires and will not be reported on separately.

Great Basin Team 5 took command of the incident at 1800 on September 6.

Evacuations: An evacuation order remains in place for the Paradise and Half-Moon Lodge areas. Please see the Curry County Sheriff’s Office website for more information. 

Fire Restrictions are in effect: Stage III fire restrictions went into effect on the Wild and Scenic Lower Rogue River on Friday, August 15, 2025. Building, maintaining, attending, or use of a fire is not permitted. To learn more, visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/rogue-siskiyou/alerts/stage-3-public-use-restrictions-wild-and-scenic-lower-rogue-river

Photo of fire behavior in the river gorge on September 10th, with smoldering and light backing activity. Photo credit: James Bartlett

title: Black Rock Fire
field_incident_description: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.

title: Isabella and Lost Girl Fires
field_incident_description:
The fires occurred in steep terrain with heavy fuel loading with little to no road access. Suppression tactics were based on several safety concerns, including a lack of ingress and egress options that would result in unacceptable medevac times. Decisions are heavily based on firefighter safety and resources at risk. Resources continue to assess for opportunities for direct and indirect options.
A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. Smoke from the fires are visible along the Hwy 56 corridor.

A closure order is pending for roads and trails in the vicinity of the fires.
field_incident_overview:
On August 31st, a lightning storm ignited 31 fires across the Kootenai National Forest.  Firefighting resources, (engines and hand crew modules) responded to these fires throughout the evening of Aug 31st and in the morning on September 1st. 10 lightning fires were ignited on the Cabinet Ranger District including the Isabella, Moran, and Lost Girl Fires which started in the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness.  Kootenai Rappelers were inserted into the Lost Girl fire on the evening of the August 31st.  Active fire behavior combined with difficult access and extremely steep and cliffy terrain compromised the safety of firefighters during this initial suppression efforts and firefighters disengaged ground operation.  A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. 

Isabella: Start Date: 09/01/2025; Size: 770 acres as of September 11, 2025

Lost Girl: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: 109 acres as of September 11, 2025

Moran Fire: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: .2 acres as of September 6, 2025 -The fire has not shown any smoke or heat for several days

*Updates will be made with any significant changes in fire behavior or growth. Updates may not occur daily.
field_title_and_unit: MTKNF Isabella and Lost Girl Fires

title: Foley Ridge Fire
field_incident_description: The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge
field_incident_overview:
The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge. 

Crews, dozers, engines, and helicopters are aggressively engaging to fully suppress the fire.
